comments.html:
If the FWSM only supports IPv6 on the main CPU then it can handle about 100 - 200 Mbps of traffic. At that point, CPU will be 100% and firewall will be dropping traffic or failing.

Effectively, this means it doesn't actually "work" with IPv6 at all.
comments.name: Etherealmind

comments.html:
For more details, read the FWSM-related comments to this post http://blog.ioshints.info/2010/11/ipv6-in-data-center-after-year-cisco-is.html

Looks like FWSM can handle a bit more than 100 Mbps, but it's very far off from the IPv4 performance.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Nexus 5000 isn't a L3 platform. It doesn't have IPv4 routing either. The data sheet says it does support IPv6 ACLs but I haven't read what the limitations are
comments.name: pg

comments.html:
The 5k now has the ability to do routing with the new 5.0(3)N1 code and the L3 expansion modules/daughtercards. Just came out.

http://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus5000/sw/release/notes/Rel_5_0_3_N1_1/Nexus5000_Release_Notes_5_0_3_N1_1_1a.html#wp316417
comments.name: SirW

comments.html: Where we are at with NAT-PT ? It was implemented in IOS quite a few years ago but it has never made it into ASA code...
comments.name: Igor Skobkarev
